commentBody: All too easy. 8:33
Pretty sure that’s the first time I’ve seen Rita Ora’s entire name used in the puzzle

Relatively easy for a Friday. Got hung up on British singers, not my strength. However, love seeing one of my favorite comedy movies SISTER ACT and my favorite movie candy SNO CAPS sitting on top of each other. Great puzzle

Hands down, the easiest Friday I've ever done.

Enjoyable.  Definitely an easy Friday puzzle
Fun puzzle, new personal record for a Friday! Quite a relief after getting beat up one side and down the other by Offerman this week!

12D reminded me of a shirt I saw someone wearing a few weeks ago. It said, with the first line big and the second line smaller:

You matter.  

Unless you multiply yourself by the speed of light squared. Then, you energy.

Not at all challenging and not really appropriate for a Friday in my estimation.  The columnist's feeling that he or she was "on the constructor's wavelength" seems to be yet another example where that functions as an (unintentional) euphemism for "this puzzle was easy".

That happens here in the comments a LOT.

It's not a bad puzzle though.

Many really easy areas for me and a few harder ones. I had a double Natick in the upper middle—never heard of Charli XCX, MIIs and couldn’t remember OSX. Figured MIIs might have to do with WIIs and guessed OSX just because there was already an X in her name so why not, and got the happy music.
BEERDARTS? I know darts are a fixture at pubs but as a drinking game I think I’m going to stay far away.
On the other side living in P&G land TIDEPOD was a gimme, VOLARE was one of my parents’ favorite songs (apparently the lounge singer’s staple after their only cruise) and who can forget SISTERACT?
As a Jewish person I know every famous Jewish athlete including Max BAER and the Dreyfuss affair is ingrained on our psyche so JACCUSE was also a gimme.
Loved ANECDATA I’m going to remember that. 
Enough BRAINDUMP from me how did it go for the rest of you?
Faster than I expected but super smooth and fun!!

I'm happy to have the occasional Friday be on the easier side  (It also usually means a tough Saturday/Sunday are around the corner...)

Surprised to see some common crosswordese in this one that was very straightforwardly clued (AER, ISAO, LET) - sometimes on Friday / Saturdays, there's no gimmes!

I had TAP water at first, because I prefer NO ICE, but that's water under the bridge...

Glad it was so easy for y'all, but that center top area was a Baer for me. Charli whaaaa??

Great to see Hemingway and Steinbeck together here. Who was the more seductive and who the terser? For the latter, Hemingway is often credited (though it's unlikely) for authoring the World's Shortest Short Story:

For sale: baby shoes, never worn.

What happens when our favorite hero undergoes some changes in late middle age?

Supermanopause.

I've heard of beer pong but finding out beer darts is a thing explains a lot about the state of ... reality. From now on when I read the news, I will remind myself "we are the species who invented beer darts", and life will make more sense.
After that easy outing I wager the Saturday will be brutal.
My fastest Friday but still a very fun puzzle. I don’t understand people who complain about answers they haven’t heard before. That’s how we learn new things.
That was easy, but thankfully no gimmicks.

Yes, @Francis, CHARLI XCX was a gimme for me, and yet even with her name in place, that section was my hardest. Didn't know the Zola letter, never heard of the word prolix (but I'll look it up as soon as I'm done here... I'm guessing it means verbose?), didn't know Applebaum, and had SCAb instead of SCAR at first. Fortunately, SNAUSAGES finally popped into my head (I'm guessing those outside the U.S. had problems with that one), as I remembered the commercial from the 80's (https://youtu.be/58YO1OgmUFM?si=cOuBaBIJ0QLCmt_i) and the rest fell into place using logic. No lookups, but it was dicey for a bit. The rest of the puzzle felt pretty straightforward. I'm surprised MENOPAUSE hasn't appeared in a NYT puzzle before. I too feel seen, Deb. TIL that the XCX part of CHARLI's name stands for Kiss Charli Kiss. She came up with it as a teen and explains it here: https://youtu.be/5sJeQa1KDrU?si=k9E2ygPLqxRPW7qH

For those of you who, either young or old, keeping score for the propositions that "these puzzles are geared to old fuddy duddies" or that "these puzzles have way too much gaming and youth slang"....

Solid corner of evidence for the latter:  A pop singer name (obviously created to be hopelessly complicated) crossed with an operating system name AND ALSO CROSSED WITH something about some kind of avatar.

I, as one geezer, am proud of recently figuring out what an avatar is.  I hope to be able to go up in one someday.

Today, in the NW, I literally fell into a septic tank and came out smelling like a rose.  Well, not literally, but it was the strangest bit of luck I can recall.

I was totally stumped in the 17A, 5 and 6D area.  Going purely by guessing.  I was in the middle of changing some combination back to a previous one, when the Congrats screen came up,.

I literally was about to change a square when I got my gold star.  And that "literally" literally means "literally".

It was a fine puzzle.  I too was on the constructor’s wavelength (which can be fun when the fill is lively).  For me, the clues were generally a bit too on-the-nose.  On the other hand, notwithstanding some xwordese like our friends RITA ORA and ISAO [Aoki], there was refreshingly little glue.

I’m currently lying in a hotel room, thankfully this puzzle was a good distraction from the fact that both the walls and the ceilings are pretty thin for the amount of money spent. 

Seriously.  Why can’t we have hotels that have sections for “quiet early to bed” folks? I would pay more for that.  The caveat being that if you’re loud in that section you have to pay double the rate. 

I’d go for that.  

Can’t wait for the room tomorrow where I know I will be in quiet central. 

And to everyone who got through yesterday’s puzzle without a relapse, well done!!! One day at a time.
I knew that we weren't learning Rita's last name for nothing.  What a thrill it was to write in her whole name!

A Steinberg! Always happy to see one of the Steinberg family creations. @Deb, I too feel seen. When I was in my early thirties , I went with my mother and a bunch of her friends to see MENOPAUSE The Musical. I remember laughing along with them, but I clearly couldn’t relate in quite the same way that she and her friends did. Fast forward two decades and hoo boy can I relate now 🤣 As for CHARLIXCX, it helps that I still have a teenager living at home 😉 SISTER ACT was one of my favorite movies and I still love to watch it (and the sequel). ANECDATA describes many of the comments posted here on the daily 🤣 A little taste of MENOPAUSE The Musical https://youtu.be/bEAKqgEw8xg?si=tSsf90ii54kica21 Thank you, Karen 😄

The cultural time span was impressive. From MIIS to SISTER ACT, VOLARE to CHARLI XCX (absolutely not a gimme for me) there is no “constructor wavelength”. 

I have never heard of SNAUSAGES which made top left a pain given that I had no idea how to spell the singer’s name. 

The rest was relatively benign.

Themeless Friday? Nah. Here's what I SEE in this grid:

In old SALEM, ECHOS of J'ACCUSE! could be heard around town, charging some with the practice of WICCA under the shadow of a LUNAR eclipse. A SISTER ACT, the townspeople exclaimed, each RECRUIT hiding their tell-tale SCAR under a cloak of SECRECY. When they gather, some bring a CAT BED for their familiars, but one dangled a black widow spider lovingly called WEB EDITOR. Another CRUSHES VINE and MOSS for some kind of potion. 

If you don't believe me, just ask ANNE RICE, who's written books about them. Or CHARLI XCX, who's reportedly playing the role of Jadis in an upcoming The Chronicles of Narnia film.

This was a weirdly unenjoyable puzzle. Most of the clues were straight out of a Monday or Tuesday, and then there was a spot that had me stumped, but for all the wrong reasons.

The tangle of the boxer, a brand of candy and "America, for one, abbr." was just cruel. I went for ConT, thinking of continent. That gave me BoER and SNOWCAnS. None of that looked like gibberish. When I did not get my gold star, that was the first area I checked with Google, and sure enough, yeah, I had made errors. I don't blame myself though as that was a triple natick, to me.

I knew the singers and ANNE Applebaum (not only because of her achievements but also, less importantly but memorably for a Polish person, because she's married to our foreign minister, Radosław Sikorski, a divisive figure on Poland's political arena). But again, that was more factual knowledge.

An overall easy puzzle made difficult in spots not by witty clues but by the inclusion of trivia and proper names - that's what I enjoy least at NYT games. If I were George the Reviewer, just Andrzej-ish, I'd rate this grid 1/10.

Oh, right,  CHARLIXCX!  One of my favorites. How could I have forgotten his name?  All my Engish friends talk about him all the time.  I think he may even have had a few duets with RITAORA (actually, RITA's been hanging around in our crosswords for a long time).

Despite having had to ask Prof. Google about Mr. XCX, I had fun solving this one.  Some witty clues, which were JEST fine with me. But still, Karen, J'ACCUSE you of sneaking in some real CRUSHErS.  SNAUSAGES?? 

(HOPI didn't hurt your feelings.)

No foothold in the Northwest. Moved on clockwise and did okay until I found myself back where I hadn’t started. I asked my grandson to please put down his game controller and answer the Nintendo clue, which he did. At which point, the crossings started to fill in and I was done. It takes a village.

Thought I was heading to a new personal best...  Felt so easy breezy....  So gentle....  But then I had to come back to the crossing of CHARL??CX with MI?S and OS? 

Couldn't get it. No idea whatsoever. Tried CHARLes, nope, us, nope. 

JACCUSE, no prob! SISTERACT, didn't give it a second thought--plopped it right in...  MENOPAUSE... really, is it that!? Gotta be! And so on.

But no amount of furrowed brows or head scratching was going to get me there with those crosses, short of an act of God, they just weren't in the bingo ball cage that is my brain, so I revealed the last couple squares after my two wrong guesses and here we are. 

But I feel good about the rest. And I finished it on our suite's balcony while listening to the 80s dance party music below and inhaling every ounce of salty sea air I can. Hey, if you have to go down, not a bad way!  ☺️
Phew, just got off the bus from Natick. I’ll take my Bacardi neat, please.

I knew Max BAER from the movie Cinderella Man (Russell Crowe). Great movie. 

Breezy Friday on my son’s 10th birthday. Played hooky and took him to a pumpkin in Petaluma. Fun day.

I wish the NYT would get their ducks in a row on presentation in their comments sections.

I am bedeviled with posting, getting a confirmatory email, and it then not appearing.

My replies to a poster are also not showing up, even with emails.

And I refuse to use the new format, which has to be significantly worse, until I absolutely have to.

I hate buggy software with a passion.
Surprised that MENOPAUSE is making its debut! Feels a worthy addition that many of us know oh too well!!

While I did struggle with the NW. I guess it was a relatively easy Friday. 

But not that fun to be honest. It was just a proper noun and definition festival. No wordplay at all. Like zero.  I’m surprised this ran. It was as dry as the Sahara. 

Brutal comment I guess. But it’s not a constructor debut. Obviously I hope for everyone else, YMMV.
On the easier side. Pretty fun.
Any angels (not brats) get the answer to 17A spoiled for them on r/CHARLIXCX? Just me?

friday hiding in wednesdays clothing.
but at least TIL anecdata.
why will the cutting "isao aoki" never take root in my brain loam and forever and always only be cultivated on crosses?
nor will both parts of "rita ora" ever fully bloom though she sprouts in some iteration on a seemingly weekly basis.

I sped through most of this puzzle until, like many it seems, I got stuck in the NW corner. I had no foothold except CHARLIXCX. I was stuck on rocks being "loose" & America being only a country until finally my brain became UNSET and LET me puzzle out the rest. The satisfaction of all the pieces clicking together at the end leaves only ECHOS of annoyance (not Alexa...sigh) and I have to say I enjoyed it!

If SNOCAPS don't exist in your country, and you haven't heard of max BAER, then SNOCAnS and BoER fit well with ConT, a pretty acceptable abbreviation for America.

I'm probably with Andrzej on this one...

Breezed through about two thirds and thought this would be - if memory serves - my second Friday with no look-ups but then had to cave and google the two singers, after which I was able to finish without much trouble, though Snocaps held me up at the end.  Never heard of them and had Boer instead of Baer.  Was happy to have plenty of clues in my wheelhouse (Zola, Steinbeck, Hemingway, Salem, Sister Act, and Anne Applebaum) to help me through.  The internet and gaming references get me every time - MIIs? OSX?  I am old.
First time ever getting sub 10 minutes on a Friday!  To quote Charli XCX: “I love it!”
Wow, very breezy. Nice entries tho!

I’ve seen a few people ask what a Mii is. If you are going to play games using Nintendo’s Wii console, then you need to create a character for yourself to use in the games. To keep it “on brand” with Wii, the character is referred to as a Mii (portmanteau of me and Wii).

Agree with others that it was way too easy for a Friday. Hopefully tomorrow's puzzle will be a challenge.

And of course we must not notice that the clue for MENOPAUSE fails to refer to the fact that only some people go through it. I cannot specify which people, or use the word "biological", for fear of being accused of a hate crime. J'ACCUSE, indeed.

I’ve been using MACS since they first arrived 40 years ago. And I was alive when Max BAER was still boxing, and learning in school when Geography class imprinted SALEM in my brain. But CHARLIXCX ?? No chance. And crossing that with an electronic game tidbit left me no choice but to run through the alphabet to fill the final square. Shameful, eh?
It still feels like cheating if one looks up the trivia answers like songs and albums.   If this was pre-internet, on paper, It seems unlikely I'd ever get past Tuesday.

A fast and breezy Friday with some interesting fill. Embarrassingly I couldn’t recall either of the British singers without a lot of help from the crosses. 
As for 30D. Don’t get me started. It may commence in one’s late 40’s, but it goes on for ever. And ever. And ever. If the other half of the human race experienced these symptoms there’d have been a revolution in care and support. Do I sound grumpy? Back off pal, I’m in the MENOPAUSE 😡😡🥵
Perhaps I need more RICE WINE? While listening to RITA ORA’s Radioactive. I’m off to grumble to the Alpacas. Their humming is very soothing, unlike the Shiba’s screaming. (We have builders in, he’s v territorial)

I'm almost positive there are some who would describe SCAR/SCAB as a Mauna LOA/KEA, but I'm here to climb on my tiny hobby-horse and say that a SCAB is a sign of healing, while a SCAR is a sign of previous injury.

Mmmpff [speaking as a quondam owner]
Franklins yes, BENS no.
It was nice seeing CAPTain America and SUPERMAN in the same puzzle.  Maybe they're here to join forces and save us.
If Tuesday and Saturday had a child....

Even though I have an iPhone and a couple of iPads, I've always been a PC girl, and had no clue about the Mac OS. Ditto for MIIS. And I seem to have been living under a rock, because I never heard of CHARLIXCS. So in the end I filled in MOSS, because it seemed right, but ended up with one wrong letter in an otherwise fairly easy puzzle.

Hottest item in our living room is the new pet bed, sometimes a CAT BED for Wiley, and sometimes a dog bed for Teddy.  They each respect the right of the other to occupy it, but when one leaves it, the other scrambles in and hunkers down, squatter’s rights.  The drama is tangible.

Today is not only the first appearance of MENOPAUSE in the Times, but in any of the major crossword outlets.  Huh!

Loved seeing side-by-side BAER NUT as well as the contradictory cross of SECRECY and I SEE, not to mention the crossing WICCA CHAIR.  

A terrific TIL – the sing-song nails-the-meaning ANECDATA, which I thought would be among the DEBUTS, but it actually showed up for the first time in 2023.  And a sweet brain ping: Hearing “Volare” in my brain exactly as I heard it from the radio all those many years ago.

Lovely mix of old and new in the box.  Thank you, Karen, for a splendid outing!

The hardest clue for me was ... SNAUSAGES, because most unusually, I knew the CHARLIE girl. I've learned TIDE and SNOCAPS, although I thought they were snow cones. 

I have ANNE Applebaum's books - excellent reads re Eastern Europe. I also recommend Postwar by Tony Judd.
Despite having to lookup Charli who I never heard of, I had a personal best less than half my Friday average. And already got genius on the bee, off to look for the Queen.

Fun puzzle today.

Easy? Wavelength? Either way, I'll take the PB.

Had [Corn]dog before NUT, Pima before HOPI, and VOLARE came naturally even without knowing the actual Italian title.

After I got WIIS and OSX I was thinking of "That singer I heard about on NPR one time", which is the extent of my knowledge of her. Close enough.

Thanks!
Bring back Robyn Weintraub. Pretty please???!!!
Great puzzle. I got hung up insisting that the smart speaker was ALEXA. Had to look up names, as always. Great start to the weekend! Happy Friday, y’all! Thanks, Karen!
Another fun Friday puzzle. Fridays never disappoint.
Wavelength is right, and when it's in sync it's awesome. Timely reminder that we're all more alike than we feel.

Do people really often confuse moss with algae? Here's a tip: if you're in a pond or lake (or other aquatic environment) it's algae. If you're walking through the woods, it's moss. But maybe I've been oversimplifying all these years. 

For too long I was looking for one name in RI?A?R?, so I missed a key piece of crosswordese. I got the gold star through perseverance. Definitely not an easy Friday for me, but in the end a satisfying solve.
What is with all of the puzzle constructors’ obsession with Rita Ora?!
That was fun and leisurely. May the rest of my Friday also be so.
Took me 1/3 the time of Wednesday’s puzzle. I needed that.
I look forward to your Thursday and Friday columns Deb—they are always humorous and I had to laugh out loud today at your 30D comment! Thanks for always brightening up my mornings :-)

I finished this around 20 percent under my Friday average, with the aid of looking up CHARLI XCX,  so not exactly the walk in the park others experienced. Still, any morning that’s temperate enough that I can sit on my deck, drink coffee, and grapple with the crossword is a good start to any day, so thank you to Karen Steinberg.

Pretty easy until the bitter end, upper middle. 

Never heard of CharliXCX. MIIS? How could anyone confuse MOSS with algae? 
Played the guessing game until I finally “solved”
this one.
But for CHARLIXCX, this would’ve been a PB.  Maybe next time!

Some days I really do feel old . I knew Rita Ora , but had no idea about Charli XCX . I have a MAC - I know it has OS operating system - could not get OSX . Initially had ED SHEERAN - which sadly has the same number of letters as CHARLI XCX - but quickly scrapped it knowing the crosses like MII and SEXIER . Just a very tough NW corner . Proud to be a fuddy duddy who completes these puzzles daily . Thank heaven for VOLARE - OH OH .
Never heard of anecdata or Charlixcx before now, but I still finished a bit under my average for Fridays.  Good puzzle!

i was quaking in my boots over the past 24 hours, hoping that i could get my gold star today and extend to a best-ever streak of 21 days (i impose very strict rules on myself to use no look ups of any kind when solving, so if i can't crack it i use "check puzzle" before reading the daily column/googling to break the streak). the northwest corner was the last to fall, but i made it! here's to the wonderful crosswords that we all enjoy, no matter how we solve them.

So, I finished with a wrong (or missing, to be more accurate) letter at the evil crossing of 17A and 6D, where someone thought I should know ANYthing about a Mac computer/platform.  (I didn't know anything about Nintendo, either, but I guessed the second i.)  This is disappointing, because some extra effort could have made that section accessible to us Olds.  The British singer was definitely not 'guessable'....

I enjoyed the solve for the most part!  Employed the ERASEr quite a lot, usually successfully.
I remember when Dino was crooning VOLARE and it was so, so popular...Right up there with "TelStar" and "Downtown" and the Early Beatles...1960-65.... on the radio.

When I saw 30D, I admit I checked the constructor's name...  In case you are a young male building a crossword, it might be wise to come up with some other, less touchy, word.  Really distressing, stressful decade of my life.  Just don't act like you know all about the lived experience.  Or labor and childbirth  either, for that matter.

It would appear that Ms. Steinberg nor Ms. Amlen have ever seen an actual EEG given the clueing and description as a “tricky clue”.  It was certainly tricky given that are no images involved with an EEG. It’s a recording of electrical impulses produced by the cortex of the brain and displayed as lines on a page.  Akin to an EKG which is t an image of the heart. 

Lots of ways to image the head/brain. EEG is not one of them.
Never heard of ANECDATA, ISAO, MIIS. Good thing this is a CROSSword puzzle, cuz I'd be lost without them. Fun solve, Karen!

Enjoyed this thoroughly even though it went fast, thanks in part to a couple of lucky stabs in the dark. I was way faster than Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday because I finally waited till morning and therefore took no catnaps mid-solve. I enjoyed Deb’s commentary, as always, and tried to imagine being someone for whom MII is a gimme and ANECDATA isn’t. MII just seems like one of the less plausible strings of letters I can think of, unless perhaps clued as 1002 old style.

Actually surprised that so many found this one unusually easy for a Friday. Tough for me with more than a couple of completely unfamiliar answers - ANECDATA, CHARLIXCX, SNAUSAGES, MIIS... and some other answers that I was never going to connect to the clues. No big deal - that's just me. And of course a puzzle find today. Thought this one was kind of cute. A Monday from May 27, 2013 by Doug Peterson. The reveal clue and answer in that one: "Blackjack player's option ... or a description of the answers to the starred clues?" DOUBLEDOWN And the answers to those starred clues (all down answers and straightforwardly clued): DURANDURAN WALLAWALLA GOODYGOODY LOUIELOUIE KNOCKKNOCK Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/27/2013&g=31&d=D I'm done. ...
Fun puzzle until the black hole of trivia BAER / SNOCAPS / BACARDI / RITA ORA / SISTERACT / ANECDATA / SALEM left a gaping hole...

I agree with Deb Amlen that this was a 'kinder, gentler' Friday puzzle.  I only needed three 'half-cheats' (using 'easy mode' clues), and thought I'd be done, but I still didn't hear the music.  So off to the Wordplay article.  I'd had 'anecdota' for ANECDATA!
So one full cheat.

I enjoyed this puzzle.  I aim a side eye to Saturday, suspecting a real bear of a puzzle.

Rather a bit of a natixcx for me up top. I remembered Brat summer with lime green everywhere, but could not remember the singer's moniker. MIIS made a sort of sense, parallelling WII. But the Mac platform could've been any combination of letters. So that was my look-up, to confirm CHARLI XCX.

BRAIN DUMP for me has always been done orally, not written.  My evidence for that is ANECDATA. Tho I guess old-fashioned diaries are basically written brain dumps.

VOLARE!
Let us leave the confusion and all disillusion behind

The first time I saw the name CHARLI XCX, I said to myself, "Some joker is going to put that in a crossword puzzle." Today, that joker was revealed. Mind you, I didn't actually say joker, but it did start with a J, as in the kind of person who would play BEER DARTS, or bite into a TIDE POD.

I'm feeling in good company that XCX was a toughie. 
I do remember the SNAUSAGES commercial, have eaten plenty of SNOCAPS (probably during SISTERACT), have consumed BACARDI, had a MII at one time, and love to sing VOLARE...so I COPED happily. Have a happy Friday.
Sitting here with CHANL__CX and don’t have a clue.

Interesting that this puzzle has appeal across generations. I am old enough to remember VOLARE (which will be my ear worm for today, and I'm not complaining!), watched Sister Act with my kids, saw SCAR on screen (no doubt with SNO CAPS) and stage, am a grandmother with a MII, and though I have heard of CHARLI XCX, I have no idea what kind of music the artist is known for. 

Now that I think about it, most themeless probably cross generations. This is probably just the first time I noticed it.

I truly enjoyed this puzzle; for a change, I won't have to finish it later, when I come home from my shift at the hospital. Meanwhile, Hubby went to the supermarket early this morning and, since flowers were BOGO today, I have two bouquets awaiting my attention. Have a lovely autumnal day, friends!

Who was excited to see MENOPAUSE in a puzzle? MII!
Let’s normalize normal.

*summons best british accent*
i wanna dance with George
nice to see ICE back in the puzzle on ICEWATER, after yesterday's "no ice" puzzle!

Great puzzle!!!! NW corner was a real toughie (for a while
I only had CHARLIXCX JEST SCAb) and did have to look up
SNAUSAGES but it all fell into place after that. Totally agree with Deb, this is a great Friday to dip your toe into!
The last couple weeks have really been kicking my butt. Lots of trivia I'm sure I'll forget just in time for them to show up in another puzzle 😅
This would have been a no-look Friday if it wasn't for those pesky SNAUSAGES! Grrrrr.

Being of a certain age, CHARLIXCX did me in.

That NW corner was a real bear.
Snausages!!!  I can hear that dog's voice from the cartoon in my mind. Hilarious. Fun puzzle.
I seemed to be on my way to a speedy Friday finish, but then too many unknowns in the NW.  Still stuck; hoping to see you again sooner rather than later.

Wow. This puzzle was simultaneously very easy and very tricky! 

The trivia was tough but attainable through crosses. 

"America, for one" = CONT? is SO TRICKY! Had me on the wrong path until I finally got SNOCAPS

I should have remembered CHARLIXCX from Kamala's 2024 campaign ("brat summer," etc.) but no, I had to google "crash brat" for the last four letters of her name.  MOSS was easy, and then it was google again to confirm MIIS and OSX, which had to be right even before I looked.  Definitely an easy Friday, especially if you allow google searches for geezers like me.

Almost everyone seems to have found this particularly easy.  While not super challenging, out of my last 12 Friday times, this was my 2nd slowest.

I knew of J'ACCUSE and CHARLI XCX, but was foggy on the spelling.  OSX was an unknown, as were ANNE and SNAUSAGES.  None of that was fatal to my solve, but it took some time to reason it out/drag it from my dusty attic.

WEB EDITORS, ECHOS, tap WATER (please, no ice for me) were not at the tip of my pencil, so it took thought to get that corner.

All in all, for me it was way easier than the toughest Friday, but not even close to my fastest.

I finished 50% faster than usual for Friday and didn't need any hints. I totally agree with Deb's column -- I think I must have been on the same wavelength as Ms. Steinberg on this one, e.g. SNAUSAGES and CHARLIXCX leapt to mind immediately (despite never having heard her music). Reading the constructor's notes was interesting as well.

Enjoyable & breezy, which isn't a bad way to get an early start on the weekend! Thanks!

Unfortunately a trivia-fest. I get Fridays are themeless but there’s so many specifics in this puzzle. If that’s your jam, have a cookie. Not for me. Got about half way and put it down. Not interested. 🍪👎

Wow, this one really made me work for it! I don't usually resort to the virtual "pencil" but today I needed to keep track of the SEVEN squares I wasn't sure of. Turns out the only true Natick for me was RITA ORA / ANECDATA. I was banging my head trying to figure out how ANECDoTA could be a thing. Clearly I need to do better keeping up with the British pop scene! The streak lives on, but it was on life support today!
question for anyone: to maintain a streak, if i have to miss a few days can i keep the streak if i go back and solve those i've missed in chronological order?

Very fast except for the upper left. I can almost always suss out answers I don’t know by running through the alphabet but the crossing of CHARLIXCX, MIIS and OSX completely stumped me. I resorted to searching ‘lyrics to Crash,’ which was no help. Then tried ‘lyrics to Brat,’ and there she was. Nice puzzle. 

I enjoyed seeing my favorite salty snack, corn NUTs and am happy to report that they are commonly available in Portugal where they are called “milho frito” which means fried corn.

FWIW, here's how I solved the crossing of 17A and 5D, neither of which I had heard of. 

At first I thought it was going to be a personal natick. "Personal" because I assumed these were not actually obscure (since the editors go to great lengths to avoid naticks). But that was no help to me. Then I figured, this being a Friday puzzle, there must be something to suggest what the missing letter was. If not I or Y, it could be any letter. So, probably I or Y (since the editors go to great lengths to avoid naticks). If an I, then 5D would be similar to the Nintendo WII, whereas MIY didn't seem to relate to anything. So I went with I.

Thinking that something is a natick seems to cause my brain to short circuit. Adopting the assumption that it is really not  doesn't guarantee a win, but does open other avenues of thought.

One person's life is another's memory which becomes a third's nostalgia and a fourth's social history. Watch the years roll by and the categories change.

Because my maternal ancestors were long-lived and had their children late (wars, exile, persecution...you know), I am only a generation away from the people in my history books in grade school. 

My grandmother grew up in a world that had never seen an airplane or even a car. Her daily newspaper would have included Victoria's death and the Russian Revolution. (Not that she needed news reports of that--she just had to look out on her village streets.)

But she lived to see the broadcast of humans landing on the moon. (Not that she believed it! It was just another drama on the box. We watched it together.) 

My first little Mac laptop in my teens, that I carried in a satchel to university with me, had more computing power than the Apollo project.
Where in this narrative is the line at which reminiscence turns to history?

Yes, both Americas are continents.  But "America" is not the name of a continent (according to how we divide up the continents over here).  

I know that other countries do it differently; even the Spanish speakers here would give you grief for not considering "America" to be the name of a continent.

Strangely, we divide Europe and Asia into two continents, much as the Old World does, but there's no logical geographical reason to do so...it's just a carryover of ancient times, when getting from one to the other basically was an ocean journey, for the most part.
